summary: Russia resumed its space biomedical research with the Bion-M 1, a 30-day unmanned biosatellite mission.

A comprehensive training and selection program was developed to co-adapt aggressive male mice for group housing and adapt them to a specialized paste food diet.
The experimental design included a spaceflight group, a ground control group that replicated flight conditions, and corresponding vivarium control groups.
The mission successfully flew mice for 30 days, combining in-flight monitoring (e.g., blood pressure) with extensive post-flight in-vivo and in-vitro analyses.
Upon return, mice were in good condition for biomedical studies and showed clear signs of disadaptation to Earth's gravity.

title: Mechanisms of Microgravity-Induced Bone Loss in Mice: Evidence for Osteocytic Osteolysis and Osteoblast Cell Cycle Arrest
author: E. Almeida
summary: A 15-day spaceflight mission (STS-131) was used to study bone loss in mice, focusing on mechanisms beyond known osteoclast activity.
Significant bone loss was observed in the pelvis, with decreases in bone volume fraction (6.29%) and thickness (11.91%).
As expected, osteoclast activity increased significantly (170%), confirming their role in space-induced bone resorption.
Novel evidence for osteocytic osteolysis was found, including enlarged osteocyte lacunae and canaliculi, supported by increased expression of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs).
Expression of the cell cycle inhibitor CDKN1a/p21 increased 3.3-fold in osteoblasts, suggesting that inhibited bone formation contributes to net bone loss.
The findings indicate that bone loss in microgravity is a multifaceted process involving osteoclast resorption, osteocytic osteolysis, and arrested bone regeneration.
This study identifies new cellular and molecular targets for developing countermeasures against bone degeneration during spaceflight.

sections.Research Purpose: To investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of bone loss during spaceflight beyond the well-established role of osteoclasts. The study hypothesized that osteocytic osteolysis (bone degradation by osteocytes) and cell cycle arrest in osteogenic progenitor cells also contribute significantly to bone degeneration in microgravity.
sections.Methods Used: Sixteen-week-old female mice were flown on the STS-131 space shuttle mission for 15 days, with a synchronous ground control group for comparison. Post-flight analyses included: micro-computed tomography (µCT) to assess bone structure and volume in the pelvis; high-resolution nano-computed tomography (nanoCT) to measure osteocyte lacunae and canaliculi dimensions; histomorphometry with TRAP staining to quantify osteoclast surfaces; and RT-qPCR to measure the expression of genes related to matrix degradation (MMPs) and cell cycle regulation (CDKN1a/p21, Trp53) in bone tissue.
sections.Key Findings: Compared to ground controls, space-flown mice exhibited: 1) Significant pelvic bone loss, with a 6.29% decrease in bone volume fraction and an 11.91% decrease in thickness. 2) A 170% increase in osteoclast-covered bone surfaces, confirming elevated bone resorption. 3) Evidence of osteocytic osteolysis, with a 17% increase in lacunar area, 14% increase in perimeter, and 6% increase in canalicular diameter. 4) Up-regulation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMP1, MMP3, MMP10) in bone, with MMP10 localized to osteocytes. 5) A 3.31-fold increase in the expression of the cell cycle inhibitor CDKN1a/p21, localized to osteoblasts.
sections.Conclusions: Microgravity-induced bone loss is not solely caused by increased osteoclastic bone resorption. This study provides new evidence that two additional mechanisms are at play: 1) osteocytic osteolysis, where osteocytes actively degrade the bone matrix around them, and 2) cell cycle arrest in osteoblasts, mediated by CDKN1a/p21, which inhibits bone formation and regeneration. These concurrent processes lead to rapid and significant bone degeneration in space.
sections.Implications & Future Work: The identification of osteocytic osteolysis and osteoblast cell cycle arrest as key contributors to spaceflight-induced bone loss presents new targets for developing effective countermeasures. Simply inhibiting osteoclasts may not be sufficient to prevent bone degeneration on long-duration missions. Future work should focus on understanding the long-term effects of these newly identified pathways and developing therapies that can simultaneously address bone resorption, stimulate bone formation, and prevent osteocytic degradation to maintain skeletal health in astronauts.

title: A Review of Microgravity's Effects on Human Cellular Biology and Health
author: Juan Izquierdo Condoy
summary: Microgravity significantly disrupts the human immune system by impairing the function of T cells, macrophages, and other immune cells, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
In cancer biology, microgravity promotes the formation of 3D multicellular spheroids from cancer cells, creating more realistic tumor models for oncology research.
The unique environment enhances tissue regeneration by modulating key signaling pathways, which improves the differentiation of stem cells into specific lineages like heart and blood cells.
At the organ level, microgravity induces accelerated bone loss, vascular remodeling, and lipid dysregulation in the liver.
Cardiomyocytes (heart muscle cells) derived from stem cells exhibit accelerated structural and functional maturation under microgravity, offering potential for cardiac disease therapies.
Research into microgravity has dual benefits: protecting astronaut health on long-duration missions and driving biomedical innovations on Earth.
Key molecular pathways affected by microgravity include RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK, NF-κB, Hippo, and PI3K-Akt, which regulate cell proliferation, inflammation, and growth.

sections.Research Purpose: To review recent advances in understanding the effects of microgravity on various biological processes and to highlight the implications and applications of these findings for both astronaut health and terrestrial medicine.
sections.Methods Used: A comprehensive literature review was conducted using PubMed, Scopus, and Embase databases. The search followed the PICOT framework to identify observational, in vitro, and experimental studies on the effects of real or simulated microgravity on various human cell types (stem, immune, cancer, bone) compared to normal gravity conditions.
sections.Key Findings: Microgravity impairs immune function by inhibiting T cell activation, disrupting macrophage differentiation, and reducing the cytotoxic activity of NK cells. It promotes the formation of 3D multicellular spheroids in cancer cells, which better mimic in vivo tumors, and can induce apoptosis. It also enhances stem cell differentiation into hematopoietic and cardiomyocyte lineages by modulating pathways like Hippo and PI3K-Akt. Organ-level effects include accelerated bone loss, endothelial dysfunction, and hepatic lipid dysregulation. Stem-cell-derived cardiomyocytes show advanced maturation, including improved mitochondrial biogenesis and calcium handling.
sections.Conclusions: Microgravity has profound and multifaceted effects on human biological systems, from cellular signaling to organ function. These findings have dual implications, presenting both challenges for space medicine (e.g., immune suppression, bone loss) and opportunities for terrestrial health (e.g., advanced models for cancer research, regenerative therapies for cardiac disease).
sections.Implications & Future Work: Continued research is essential for developing countermeasures to protect astronaut health during long-duration space missions. Furthermore, leveraging microgravity as a research tool can foster significant biomedical innovations in oncology, immunology, and regenerative medicine, potentially leading to transformative therapeutic applications on Earth.

title: Bion-M 1 Mission: Experimental Design and Training Program for Mouse Biomedical Research in Space
author: Andrievsky, A.A.
summary: Russia resumed its space biomedical research with the Bion-M 1 biosatellite, a 30-day mission utilizing male mice to study physiological adaptation to microgravity.
The primary scientific goal was to investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms behind how key physiological systems adapt to long-term spaceflight.
The experimental design integrated in-flight measurements, such as continuous blood pressure monitoring, with extensive post-flight in vivo and in vitro studies.
A significant challenge was group-housing aggressive male C57BL/6N mice, which required a specialized pre-flight training and co-adaptation program.
This training also included adapting mice to a paste food diet and using behavioral tests to select homogenous groups for the experiments.
The mission was successful, with mice returning in good condition but showing signs of disadaptation to Earth's gravity.
The study concluded that the training program was effective, confirming that group-housed male mice are a viable model for long-duration space biomedical research.

sections.Research Purpose: To elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems (musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, sensorimotor, nervous) to long-term microgravity exposure and the subsequent re-adaptation period on Earth.
sections.Methods Used: Male C57BL/6N mice were flown for 30 days aboard the Bion-M 1 biosatellite. A ground control group replicated the flight environmental conditions. A pre-flight training program was implemented to co-adapt male mice for group housing and acclimate them to a paste food diet. Research combined in vivo measurements (in-flight video, continuous blood pressure telemetry) and post-flight functional tests with extensive in vitro analyses (morphological, biochemical, molecular) of numerous tissues and organs harvested after the mission.
sections.Key Findings: The 30-day Bion-M 1 mission was successfully completed, and the mice returned in good condition for subsequent biomedical studies. Post-flight, the mice displayed pronounced signs of disadaptation to Earth's gravity. The pre-flight training program designed to mitigate aggression and adapt male mice to group housing and experimental conditions proved to be effective.
sections.Conclusions: The training and selection program was successful, demonstrating that male mice can be effectively used in long-duration space biomedical research, even when group-housed. The experimental design provides a robust framework for future studies.
sections.Implications & Future Work: This mission successfully re-established Russia's biosatellite research program. The positive outcome validates the use of group-housed male mice, a common laboratory model, for complex spaceflight studies. The comprehensive data collected will be used for in-depth analysis of spaceflight's effects and the dynamics of re-adaptation to gravity, paving the way for future research on recovery mechanisms.

title: Microgravity-Induced Bone Loss in Mice: Evidence for Osteocytic Osteolysis and Osteoblast Cell Cycle Arrest
author: E. Almeida
summary: A study was conducted on mice exposed to microgravity for 15 days on the STS-131 space shuttle mission to investigate mechanisms of bone loss.
Significant bone loss was confirmed in the pelvis, with decreased bone volume fraction (6.29%) and thickness (11.91%).
Beyond known osteoclast-mediated resorption (which increased by 170%), the study provides new evidence for osteocytic osteolysis.
Signs of osteocytic osteolysis include enlarged osteocyte lacunae (+17% area), increased canalicular diameter, and up-regulation of matrix-degrading enzymes (MMPs).
Researchers also identified a potential cell cycle arrest in bone-forming osteoblasts, indicated by a 3.31-fold increase in the gene CDKN1a/p21.
The apoptosis-inducing gene Trp53 was down-regulated, suggesting a survival-promoting mechanism alongside the cell cycle arrest.
These findings suggest bone loss in space is a multifaceted process involving osteoclasts, osteocytes, and osteoblasts, with implications for long-duration missions.

sections.Research Purpose: To investigate the hypothesis that microgravity-induced bone loss is not solely caused by osteoclast-mediated resorption, but also involves contributions from osteocytic osteolysis (bone degradation by osteocytes) and cell cycle arrest in osteogenic (bone-forming) cells.
sections.Methods Used: Female C57BL/6J mice were flown on the STS-131 space shuttle mission for 15 days, with a synchronous ground control group. Post-flight analyses on pelvic and femoral bone included: micro-computed tomography (µCT) for bone structure; high-resolution nanoCT for osteocyte lacunae morphology; histomorphometry with TRAP staining for osteoclast activity; and RT-qPCR for gene expression analysis of key markers related to matrix degradation (MMPs), cell cycle arrest (CDKN1a/p21), and apoptosis (Trp53).
sections.Key Findings: Compared to ground controls, mice exposed to microgravity exhibited: a 6.29% decrease in pelvic bone volume fraction and an 11.91% decrease in bone thickness; a 170% increase in osteoclast-covered bone surfaces; a 17% increase in osteocyte lacunar cross-sectional area and a 14% increase in perimeter, indicating osteocytic osteolysis; significant up-regulation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMP1, MMP3, MMP10), with MMP10 localized to osteocytes; a 3.31-fold increase in the expression of the cell cycle inhibitor CDKN1a/p21, localized to osteoblasts; a 1.54-fold decrease in the expression of the apoptosis inducer Trp53.
sections.Conclusions: Bone loss in microgravity is a rapid and complex process involving more than just increased osteoclast activity. This study provides the first evidence that microgravity induces osteocytic osteolysis and a CDKN1a/p21-mediated cell cycle arrest in osteogenic cells, identifying new cellular mechanisms contributing to skeletal degradation in space.
sections.Implications & Future Work: The findings imply that countermeasures for spaceflight-induced bone loss may need to target multiple cell types and pathways, including osteocytes and osteoblast proliferation, not just osteoclast activity. The up-regulation of CDKN1a/p21 suggests a potential for broader deficits in tissue regeneration during long-duration spaceflight, warranting further investigation. Future work should continue to explore these novel pathways to better predict long-term effects and develop more effective countermeasures.

title: A Review of Microgravity's Impact on Human Cellular Processes and Health
author: Juan Izquierdo-Condoy
summary: Microgravity significantly dysregulates the human immune system by impairing the function of key cells like T cells and macrophages and disrupting critical signaling pathways.

In cancer research, microgravity promotes the formation of three-dimensional multicellular spheroids that closely mimic in vivo tumors, providing a valuable model for studying tumor biology and treatment.
The unique environment enhances tissue regeneration by modulating signaling pathways that improve stem cell differentiation into specialized cells, such as hematopoietic and cardiomyocyte lineages.
Cardiomyocytes cultured in microgravity exhibit advanced structural and functional maturation, indicating potential for developing novel therapies for cardiac diseases like myocardial infarction.
At the organ level, microgravity induces accelerated bone loss, lipid dysregulation through altered hepatic metabolism, and vascular remodeling.

Research into microgravity's biological effects has dual importance: ensuring astronaut health on long-duration missions and driving biomedical innovations on Earth in regenerative medicine, oncology, and immunology.

sections.Research Purpose: To review and summarize recent scientific advances in understanding the effects of microgravity on various biological processes, emphasizing the implications and applications for both astronaut health during space missions and terrestrial medicine.
sections.Methods Used: A comprehensive literature review was conducted using the PubMed, Scopus, and Embase databases. The search strategy followed the PICOT framework to identify observational, in vitro, and experimental studies on various cell types (stem, immune, cancer, etc.) under microgravity, with outcomes focused on cell proliferation, tissue regeneration, cellular metabolism, and immune function.
sections.Key Findings: Microgravity induces widespread immune dysfunction, including impaired T cell activation, reduced cytokine production, and accelerated apoptosis, disrupting key signaling pathways like RAS, ERK, and NF-κB. It promotes the formation of 3D multicellular spheroids in cancer cells, which increases apoptosis and alters gene expression related to tumor progression. The environment enhances the differentiation and maturation of stem cells, particularly human pluripotent stem cells into cardiomyocytes, which show improved mitochondrial function, calcium handling, and structural integrity. Organ-level effects include accelerated bone loss, hepatic lipid dysregulation, and vascular remodeling.
sections.Conclusions: Microgravity exerts profound and multifaceted effects on human biological systems from the cellular to the organ level. While it presents significant challenges to astronaut health, such as immune suppression and bone density loss, it also serves as a unique environmental tool for advancing biomedical research and understanding fundamental biological mechanisms.
sections.Implications & Future Work: The findings have dual applications for space medicine and terrestrial health. Continued research is crucial for developing countermeasures to protect astronauts on long-duration missions. On Earth, this research can accelerate the development of regenerative therapies (especially for cardiac diseases), create more accurate cancer models for drug testing, and provide new insights for immunological interventions.

title: Overview of Mouse Biomedical Research on the Bion-M 1 Biosatellite Mission
author: A. Andrievsky
summary: Russia resumed its space biomedical research with the successful 30-day Bion-M 1 biosatellite mission after a 16-year hiatus.
The mission used group-housed male C57BL/6 mice as the principal species to study adaptation to long-term microgravity.
Research combined in-flight measurements like continuous blood pressure with extensive post-flight in vivo and in vitro analyses of multiple physiological systems.
A key component was a pre-flight training program to co-adapt the aggressive male mice for group housing and adapt them to a paste food diet.
Experimental controls included a ground-based group replicating spacecraft conditions and vivarium groups to account for housing and seasonal effects.
The mission was successful, with mice returning in good condition but showing pronounced disadaptation to Earth's gravity, validating the experimental approach.
The study demonstrated that with proper training, male mice can be successfully employed in long-duration space biomedical research.

sections.Research Purpose: To elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems—including muscle, bone, cardiovascular, sensorimotor, and nervous systems—to long-term (30-day) microgravity exposure and to study the dynamics of re-adaptation to Earth's gravity post-flight.
sections.Methods Used: Male C57BL/6N mice were flown for 30 days aboard the Bion-M 1 biosatellite. A comprehensive pre-flight training program was implemented to adapt the mice to group housing and a paste food diet. The experiment included a spaceflight (SF) group, a ground control (GC) group in a replica habitat, and corresponding vivarium control groups. Data collection involved in-flight in vivo measurements (video, continuous arterial pressure), post-flight in vivo testing (behavior, strength, telemetry), and extensive post-flight in vitro analyses (morphological, biochemical, molecular) of numerous harvested organs and tissues.
sections.Key Findings: The 30-day orbital mission with group-housed male mice was successfully completed. Upon return, the mice were in good condition for subsequent biomedical studies. The animals displayed clear signs of pronounced disadaptation to Earth's gravity. The pre-flight training and selection program proved effective for ensuring the welfare of the mice and the success of the mission, demonstrating the viability of using group-housed male mice in long-duration spaceflight.
sections.Conclusions: The training program and experimental design for the Bion-M 1 mission were effective, demonstrating that group-housed male mice can be successfully utilized for complex, long-duration space biomedical research. The mission successfully gathered a wide range of data on both adaptation to microgravity and re-adaptation to Earth's gravity, providing a robust foundation for detailed future analyses.
sections.Implications & Future Work: This mission successfully validates the male mouse as a model organism for long-duration spaceflight studies, enabling research that can leverage genetic engineering and larger sample sizes. The comprehensive dataset collected will fuel future work analyzing the specific cellular and molecular mechanisms of spaceflight adaptation. The success of Bion-M 1 re-establishes a key platform for Russian space bioscience and informs the design of future experiments.

title: Mechanisms of Microgravity-Induced Bone Loss in Mice: Osteocytic Osteolysis and Osteoblast Cell Cycle Arrest
author: E. Almeida
summary: Female mice flown for 15 days on the STS-131 space shuttle mission were studied to understand the mechanisms of bone loss in microgravity.
Significant bone loss was confirmed in the pelvis, evidenced by decreased bone volume fraction and thickness.
In addition to a 170% increase in osteoclast activity, the study provides new evidence for osteocytic osteolysis—the degradation of bone by embedded osteocytes.
High-resolution nanoCT imaging revealed enlargement of osteocyte lacunae (cavities) and canaliculi (channels) in flight mice.
Gene expression analysis showed increased levels of matrix-degrading enzymes (MMPs) associated with osteocytes.
The cell cycle inhibitor CDKN1a/p21 was upregulated in bone-forming cells (osteoblasts), suggesting a halt in bone regeneration.
These findings indicate that bone loss in space is a complex process involving not just increased resorption but also osteocytic degradation and impaired formation.

sections.Research Purpose: To investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying bone degeneration in space beyond the well-known osteoclast-mediated resorption. The study hypothesized that two other processes contribute to bone loss: osteocytic osteolysis (degradation of bone matrix by osteocytes) and cell cycle arrest in osteogenic cells, which would impair bone formation and regeneration.
sections.Methods Used: 16-week-old female C57BL/6J mice were exposed to microgravity for 15 days aboard the STS-131 space shuttle mission, with a synchronous ground control group. Post-flight analyses included: micro-computed tomography (µCT) to assess pelvic bone structure and volume; high-resolution nano-computed tomography (nanoCT) to analyze osteocyte lacunae and canaliculi at the nanoscale; TRAP staining to quantify osteoclast activity; and RT-qPCR to measure the expression of key genes related to matrix degradation (MMPs), cell cycle arrest (CDKN1a/p21), and apoptosis (Trp53).
sections.Key Findings: Compared to ground controls, space-flown mice exhibited: 1) A significant decrease in pelvic bone volume fraction (6.29%) and thickness (11.91%). 2) A 170% increase in TRAP-positive osteoclast surfaces, confirming heightened bone resorption. 3) Evidence of osteocytic osteolysis, including a 17% increase in lacunar area, a 14% increase in perimeter, and a 6% increase in canalicular diameter. 4) Significant up-regulation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMP1, MMP3, MMP10) in bone tissue. 5) A 3.31-fold increase in the expression of the cell cycle inhibitor CDKN1a/p21, which was localized to osteoblasts. 6) A 1.54-fold down-regulation of the apoptosis inducer Trp53.
sections.Conclusions: The bone degeneration observed in mice after short-duration spaceflight is a multi-faceted process. It is not limited to increased osteoclastic bone resorption. This study provides strong new evidence for the contribution of two additional mechanisms: microgravity-induced osteocytic osteolysis and CDKN1a/p21-mediated cell cycle arrest in the osteogenic lineage, which likely inhibits tissue regeneration.
sections.Implications & Future Work: These findings identify osteocytes and osteoblast cell cycle regulation as novel targets for developing countermeasures to prevent bone loss during long-duration space missions. The upregulation of CDKN1a/p21 suggests that microgravity may cause broader deficits in tissue regeneration beyond bone. Future work could investigate these mechanisms over longer spaceflight durations to determine if adaptation occurs and explore the specific signaling pathways that trigger osteocytic osteolysis and cell cycle arrest in response to mechanical unloading.

title: A Review of the Effects of Microgravity on Human Cellular Processes and Health
author: Juan Izquierdo Condoy
summary: Microgravity significantly impairs the human immune system by disrupting T cell activation, cytokine production, and macrophage differentiation, increasing infection susceptibility.
In oncology, microgravity promotes the formation of 3D multicellular spheroids from cancer cells, creating more realistic models for studying tumor dynamics and treatments.
The environment enhances tissue regeneration by modulating key signaling pathways, improving stem cell differentiation into hematopoietic and cardiomyocyte lineages.
At the organ level, microgravity induces negative changes, including accelerated bone loss, lipid dysregulation in the liver, and adverse vascular remodeling.
Cardiomyocytes cultured in microgravity exhibit advanced structural and functional maturation, presenting opportunities for developing new therapies for cardiac diseases.
Microgravity's effects are mediated by alterations in critical molecular signaling pathways like RAS-ERK, NF-κB, Hippo, and PI3K-Akt.
These findings have dual implications: protecting astronaut health during space missions and advancing biomedical innovations on Earth, particularly in regenerative medicine and cancer research.

sections.Research Purpose: To review recent advances in understanding the effects of microgravity on biological processes and to explore the implications and applications of these findings for human health, both in space and on Earth.
sections.Methods Used: A comprehensive literature review was conducted using PubMed, Scopus, and Embase databases. The search was structured using the PICOT framework to identify studies on various cell types (stem cells, T cells, cancer cells, etc.) under microgravity conditions compared to normal gravity, focusing on outcomes like cell proliferation, tissue regeneration, and immune health.
sections.Key Findings: Microgravity impairs immune cell function, notably T cell activation and proliferation. It promotes the formation of 3D multicellular spheroids in cancer cells, mimicking in vivo tumors and altering gene expression related to proliferation. It enhances stem cell differentiation and maturation, especially for cardiomyocytes, which show improved mitochondrial function and structural development. It also causes systemic physiological changes, including bone density loss, altered liver metabolism, and vascular remodeling.
sections.Conclusions: Microgravity exerts a profound and multifaceted influence on human biological systems. While it presents significant health challenges for astronauts, such as immune dysfunction and bone loss, it also serves as a unique tool for biomedical research. The environment offers novel insights into disease modeling (e.g., cancer spheroids) and regenerative medicine (e.g., cardiomyocyte maturation), highlighting its dual role as both a stressor and an opportunity for innovation.
sections.Implications & Future Work: The findings are critical for developing countermeasures to protect astronaut health on long-duration space missions. They also hold transformative potential for terrestrial medicine, including advancements in regenerative therapies for cardiac disease, new strategies for oncology research, and novel immunological interventions. Continued research is essential to fully leverage these opportunities and mitigate the risks associated with space travel.

title: Experimental Design and Mouse Training for the Bion-M 1 Biosatellite Mission
author: A. Andrievsky
summary: Russia's Bion-M 1 mission conducted a 30-day spaceflight to study the physiological effects of microgravity on male C57BL/6 mice.
The research aimed to uncover cellular and molecular mechanisms of adaptation in systems like the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and nervous systems.
The study integrated in-flight and post-flight 'in vivo' measurements (e.g., blood pressure, behavior) with comprehensive post-flight 'in vitro' tissue analyses.
A specialized pre-flight training program was successfully implemented to co-adapt normally aggressive male mice for group housing and a paste food diet.
The experimental design included spaceflight, ground control, and vivarium control groups to isolate the effects of microgravity.
Upon return, mice were in good health but showed clear signs of disadaptation to Earth's gravity, validating the model for space biology studies.
The mission's success demonstrated that male mice are a viable model for long-duration space biomedical research.

sections.Research Purpose: To investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems to long-term microgravity and subsequent re-adaptation to Earth's gravity, using a male mouse model aboard the 30-day Bion-M 1 biosatellite mission.
sections.Methods Used: Male C57BL/6N mice were divided into a spaceflight group, a ground control group replicating flight conditions, and corresponding vivarium controls. A pre-flight training program adapted the mice to group housing and a paste food diet. The study combined 'in vivo' methods, including in-flight telemetry for continuous blood pressure monitoring and post-flight behavioral tests, with extensive post-flight 'in vitro' analyses of various tissues using morphological, biochemical, and molecular-biology techniques.
sections.Key Findings: The 30-day automated spaceflight mission was completed successfully, with the mice returning in good condition for subsequent studies. The flight group displayed pronounced signs of disadaptation to Earth's gravity upon return. The pre-flight training program was effective in ensuring animal welfare and co-adaptation of group-housed male mice, which is typically a challenge.
sections.Conclusions: The training and selection program was effective, and male mice can be successfully employed as a model organism in long-duration space biomedical research. The Bion-M 1 mission successfully provided a platform for comprehensive study of microgravity's effects and re-adaptation to normal gravity.
sections.Implications & Future Work: The success of this mission validates the use of the mouse, a powerful genetic model, for future long-duration spaceflight research, enabling deeper molecular investigations into adaptation mechanisms. The comprehensive dataset generated will inform the development of countermeasures for human spaceflight and guide the design of future experiments following post-flight recovery dynamics.
